vclaim: She says Elizabeth Warren has a racist statue in her kitchen.
date: stated on January 16, 2019 in a Facebook post:
title: No, Elizabeth Warren doesn't have racist art in her kitchen.
text: After Elizabeth Warren made a direct question about Instagram on New Year's Eve, several news outlets focused on the beer that I tore up in front of the camera. But the other viewers were more surprising than the art that decorated her kitchen closet. "Raciality so much"? On the New York Republicans' page, which shows a picture of Warren in front of the Cabinet, along with an offensive cartoon of a black boy eating a melon. One of the pieces on her locker is round in yellow, indicating that this is the racist art in question. The article was referred to as part of Facebook efforts to combat false news and misleading information in its news broadcast. ∙ (Read more about our partnership with Facebook.) The letter of PolitiFact was sent to the New York City Republican account on Facebook about the photo that was not immediately answered. However, the images appeared on the Internet elsewhere more than a week ago. "Does Elizabeth Warren have black-faced statues in her house?" Ask Jan 4 about Reddit. On the same day, Tommy Lahern, a contributor to Fox News, copied a similar picture (which has since been deleted). "Do I see this right?" She said. Facebook was published on January 11, 2021 in the Facebook newspaper Nancy Belusi, who was no longer the Speaker of the House of Representatives by Samantha Buterman: January 12, 2021, not according to Warren. Her campaign posted two pictures of her kitchen closet from different angles that show the statue is actually a vase, and it's a vase. "The right-wing calculations on Twitter pay for conspiracy theory that Elizabeth has a racist artifact in her kitchen," says the website. "It is clear that the body does not match the group, and you can see for yourself in the images below that the body is actually a Greek jar." We're assessing this allegation pants on fire! On January 31, the Republicans in New York City responded to Paulette Fuckett's letter about the article and said it was withdrawn. "It seems that it was published by Tommy Lahern on Twitter," said the team in Facebook, "and one of the managers of this page published it. We removed it after we found out it wasn't true!"
